importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The day before the IMO vote, President Trump made a public threat on Truth Social against a global carbon tax on shipping, prompting immediate diplomatic and procedural reactions in London.
The final decision to delay the Net Zero Framework adoption was announced on this date, marking a pivotal moment in international climate policy.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The formal adoption of the Net Zero Framework was delayed until late 2025, setting back global efforts to regulate shipping emissions by at least 12 months.
The IMO aims to reduce net shipping emissions by 20% by 2030 and eliminate them entirely by 2050, a timeline directly challenged by the postponement.

keyTakeAways: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) delayed formal adoption of the Net Zero Framework (NZF) by at least 12 months due to pressure from U.S. President Donald Trump.
Trump publicly condemned the IMO's plan as a 'Global Green New Scam Tax' and threatened sanctions, visa restrictions, and port levies on countries supporting the emissions regulation.
The vote resulted in a 57-49 decision to postpone, with countries like Argentina and Singapore switching from support to opposition.
The NZF would have been the first global carbon-pricing system for shipping, imposing a $380 penalty per metric tonne of CO2-equivalent emissions.
The framework aims to cut shipping emissions by 20% by 2030 and achieve net-zero by 2050, a critical step in combating climate change affecting ocean currents and storm frequency.
Despite the delay, international bodies like the UN and the International Chamber of Shipping continue to emphasize the urgency and importance of decarbonizing maritime transport.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) postponed the formal adoption of its Net Zero Framework (NZF), which would have introduced a global carbon tax on shipping emissions, by at least 12 months. This decision followed a public threat by U.S. President Donald Trump, who labeled the plan a 'Global Green New Scam Tax' and threatened sanctions on countries supporting it. The vote, which passed 57-49 in favor of delay, saw key allies like China, the EU, and Britain maintain support, while Russia, Saudi Arabia, Argentina, and Singapore opposed or withdrew support. The NZF, if adopted, would have charged ships $380 per metric ton of CO2-equivalent emissions and aimed to cut shipping emissions by 20% by 2030 and eliminate them by 2050. Critics, including UN officials and the International Chamber of Shipping, argue that the delay undermines global climate goals and industry readiness for decarbonization, especially as climate change already disrupts ocean systems and shipping safety.
title: Trump torpedoes international deal to reduce shipping emissions
